<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_strict_:
```c
size_t
MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_strict_ (char *str)
{
#ifdef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  size_t res;
  bool broken;

  res = MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_ (str, &broken);
  if (broken)
  {
    res = 0;
    str[0] = 0;
  }
  return res;
#else  /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
  size_t r;
  size_t w;
  r = 0;
  w = 0;

  while (0 != str[r])
  {
    const char chr = str[r++];
    if ('%' == chr)
    {
      const char d1 = str[r++];
      if (0 == d1)
        return 0;
      else
      {
        const char d2 = str[r++];
        if (0 == d2)
          return 0;
        else
        {
          const int h = toxdigitvalue (d1);
          const int l = toxdigitvalue (d2);
          unsigned char out;
          if ((0 > h) || (0 > l))
            return 0;
          out =
            (unsigned char) (((uint8_t) (((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) h)) << 4))
                             | ((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) l)));
          str[w++] = (char) out;
        }
      }
    }
    else
      str[w++] = chr;
  }
  str[w] = 0;
  return w;
#endif /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
str[w++] = chr;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 applies to the use of functions from <string.h> (memcpy, memset, strcpy, etc.). The fragment str[w++] = chr; does not call any <string.h> function. Moreover, within the decoding loop the invariant w <= r holds (each iteration increments r at least as much as w), so writes to str[w++] and the final str[w] = 0 occur at or before the original null terminator and do not extend past the original string contents. The only ways an out‑of‑bounds access could occur here are if the input pointer str is invalid or the input is not properly null‑terminated (which would already be undefined behavior on the reads) — these are not violations of Rule 21.17.
